Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Language Ideologies, Conservation Ideologies: Multilingualism and Collaboration in Transnational Environmental Work

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Environmental conservation efforts are often directed to regions of the world that have high levels of biodiversity. Such areas frequently have high levels of linguistic diversity, as well. This means that the difficulties of bringing about coordination and cooperation among diverse stakeholders are all too often compounded by miscommunications and misunderstandings resulting from linguistic failure. Successful conservation requires collaboration between scientists, educators, hunters, farmers, policy makers, and citizens, all of whom may have different goals and hold different beliefs about the environment. How is such collaboration possible when people must work across multiple languages to communicate? When is it successful? When and why does it fail? To answer these questions, University of California Los Angeles anthropology doctoral candidate Rosalie Edmonds, supervised by Dr. Paul V. Kroskrity, will conduct a close anthropological and linguistic investigation of communication and collaboration in a site that is both highly bio-diverse and deeply multi-lingual. Examining how varied stakeholders work together in this site will enable the creation of appropriate policies and practices for multi-lingual workplaces wherever they may occur.

The research will take place at the Limbe Wildlife Centre in Cameroon, Central Africa. This is an appropriate site for this investigation because in addition to English and French, Cameroon is home to 280 indigenous languages and the Centre is also visited by tourists who speak yet more languages. Despite these major lingustic challenges, the Centre has successfully rescued and rehabilitated animals for over twenty years, while also providing environmental education programming in local schools and rural communities, and serving as a tourist destination. In such a diverse context, what languages do people use to communicate with each other, and how do they resolve misunderstandings? The researcher will collect data by observing how people collaborate to solve environmental problems. She will record daily activities and natural language interactions; conduct interviews to explore people's beliefs about conservation work and perceptions of communication; and carry out participant observation to gain an insider understanding. By combining approaches from linguistic and environmental anthropology, this research document how people talk about, conceptualize, and perform conservation-related tasks in a multilingual environment, and what impact their talk has on how the work is accomplished. Clarifying how people communicate and work together in this situation will permit a new perspective on how global problems can be successfully negotiated in transnational, multilingual settings. Additionally, this research will develop practical materials to facilitate cross-cultural communication, including language guides, and a best practices workshop for communicating with people from different backgrounds.

POR.DRECONTENT:
With the generous assistance of the National Science Foundation Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement Grant, the student researcher conducted ethnographic and linguistic fieldwork between January and September of 2018. This fieldwork was conducted at the Limbe Wildlife Centre in southwestern Cameroon, a sanctuary chosen for its reputation for successful conservation work in the midst of great cultural, linguistic, and ideological diversity. Multilingualism is an essential component of the LWC’s work, as staff use some of Cameroon’s 280 indigenous languages alongside the official languages of French and English, and international visitors bring other languages to the already fraught work of wildlife conservation. In this way, the conservation of Cameroon’s biological diversity requires a negotiation of its linguistic diversity.

This research therefore asked: how does collaboration take place, despite all of the linguistic, cultural, and ideological contestation that exist within the LWC? The student researcher answered this question through a close examination of the everyday communicative practices that occur as Cameroonian animal keepers, French NGO managers, and European volunteers work together to care for animals rescued from illegal wildlife trafficking. Through the analysis of field notes, interviews, and video recording of workplace interactions, the student researcher found that although everyone at the LWC orients to English as the main language of communication, English is rarely anyone’s first or preferred language, and the bulk of work at the LWC occurs instead in French or Cameroonian Pidgin English – languages that are unequally available to different people at the LWC. Additionally, management, staff, and volunteers hold different motivations for and ideologies about working with animals – while management take a scientific, primatological perspective, keepers’ approaches generally focus more on the practical contingencies involved in animal care, and many volunteers come with little to no knowledge, but simply a love for animals. Despite these differences, the LWC maintains an international reputation for successful conservation work, caring for 300 animals, conducting environmental education programs in local schools, and hosting 50,000 tours each year.

The findings from this project, in the form of the dissertation and academic journal articles, will contribute to the discipline of anthropology, as well as related fields such as sociology or applied linguistics that use ethnographic and/or linguistic methods. This project is innovative both methodologically and theoretically through its use of linguistic analysis to examine the politics of environmental conservation. Misunderstandings lie at the heart of much anthropological work on environmental conservation, varying from the benefits of conservation, to definitions of nature, to relationships between people. As these misunderstandings often originate in conversations between multilingual individuals, an examination of the politics of language choice and collaboration in interaction offers a new perspective on how conflicts occur and are negotiated.

This project may also impact work in African studies, where linguistic work continues to focus on documenting the distribution and grammatical features of particular languages. This project instead provides an example of the way these languages are used on the ground in daily work practices, as well as the effects of not only language use itself, but individuals’ ideologies about language practices. Finally, this work contributes to fields such as primatology, zoology, and conservation biology, as it critically examines the practices which produce primatological knowledge, and the ways in which that knowledge is used. It additionally puts primatological knowledge alongside the practical knowledge of animal keepers, offering strategies through which these two types of knowledge can be complementary in conservation work.

Deforestation, wildlife trafficking, and unsustainable forms of agriculture pose significant threats to both the long-term maintenance of global biodiversity and the health and livelihoods of local people. Solutions to these problems require multiple types of expertise, transmitted in multiple languages – from the scientific community and government policies, and also from conservation staff, volunteers, and local people who carry out this work on the ground. In addition to its academic contributions, this project provides practical interventions for both environmental policy and local institutional programming. The first of these interventions occurred in September 2017 and March 2018, when the researcher held workshops on communication at the Limbe Wildlife Centre. These workshops not only gave an overview of the research conducted and its anticipated results, but also outlined common problems and potential solutions for misunderstandings that occur – particularly between keepers and volunteers. The subsequent discussion between staff, management, volunteers, and the researcher resulted in a request for future materials (language guides, volunteer orientations, etc.) to be developed by the researcher to further aid in volunteer and staff training and development. By better understanding how to balance the competing ideas that people of different backgrounds bring into spaces like the LWC, the way they communicate these ideas, and how that communication can break down, this project furthers the work of institutions like the Limbe Wildlife Centre, as well as the conservation movement at large.
